docs.snippet: A cat resembling E. T. and bearing his name is in town from Paris to join 800 participants in an international cat show that opens this evening (5 to 10 P.M.) and continues Saturday and Sunday (9 A.M. to 6 P.M.) at Madison Square Garden. The extra...
docs.lead_paragraph: A cat resembling E. T. and bearing his name is in town from Paris to join 800 participants in an international cat show that opens this evening (5 to 10 P.M.) and continues Saturday and Sunday (9 A.M. to 6 P.M.) at Madison Square Garden. The extra-terrestrial lookalike has no hair or whiskers, huge ears that stick out from the sides of its head, wrinkly skin and an amiable disposition - a new breed called Sphinx that resulted from a mutation. E. T. will vie with cats of three other new but not officially recognized breeds. Most entries, however, are recognized breeds competing in five categories: pedigreed kittens, adults and altered cats, and nonpedigreed kittens and adult household pets. Admission: $6 ($4 for over-65's and under-12's). Information: 564-4400. A SPACE FESTIVAL

docs.snippet: ''IF there is still such a thing as high   society, it's certainly here tonight!'' one partygoer said early in the evening as some 800 guests made their way to their flower-bedecked tables at the New York State Theater Promenade after a performanc...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''IF there is still such a thing as high society, it's certainly here tonight!'' one partygoer said early in the evening as some 800 guests made their way to their flower-bedecked tables at the New York State Theater Promenade after a performance by the New York City Ballet Wednesday night. ''Definitely the party of January!'' Evelyn Lauder said several hours later. The black-tie January Garden Party was the seventh annual School of American Ballet Gala Benefit. It raised $800,000 and, seemingly, the spirits of most of the elegantly clad crowd, which included names like Astor, Getty, Drexel, Rockefeller, Rothschild and Vanderbilt.

docs.snippet: Members of the church-based sanctuary movement for Central American refugees, meeting here, were buoyed today when a Roman Catholic lay worker was acquitted in Texas on charges of transporting illegal aliens.     Nine sanctuary workers who face si...
docs.lead_paragraph: Members of the church-based sanctuary movement for Central American refugees, meeting here, were buoyed today when a Roman Catholic lay worker was acquitted in Texas on charges of transporting illegal aliens. Nine sanctuary workers who face similar indictments here vowed that they would ''continue to engage in sanctuary ministry.'' A jury in Corpus Christi, Tex., took less than two hours to acquit the worker, 41-year-old Jack Elder, director of a half-way house for Central Americans, of three counts of illegally transporting aliens inside the United States. He Cites Religious Conviction Both Mr. Elder and the Government agreed on the essential facts of the case: Last March Mr. Elder gave three undocumented Salvadorans a ride from the Casa Oscar Romero half-way house at San Benito some 30 miles to a bus station at Harlingen.

headline.main: CHURCH WORKER ACQUITTED IN ALIEN CASE, BUOYING MOVEMENT

docs.snippet: The General Foods Corporation reported yesterday that its net income fell 25.2 percent in the third fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 29. It blamed the strong dollar and lower earnings from powdered beverages and its Oscar Mayer meat subsidiary....
docs.lead_paragraph: The General Foods Corporation reported yesterday that its net income fell 25.2 percent in the third fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 29. It blamed the strong dollar and lower earnings from powdered beverages and its Oscar Mayer meat subsidiary.

docs.snippet: Leaders of El Salvador's leftist opposition said here today that chances for future peace talks had been damaged by a ''political crisis'' in the Government of President Jose Napoleon Duarte.   The rebel leaders, speaking at a briefing for reporte...
docs.lead_paragraph: Leaders of El Salvador's leftist opposition said here today that chances for future peace talks had been damaged by a ''political crisis'' in the Government of President Jose Napoleon Duarte. The rebel leaders, speaking at a briefing for reporters, said Mr. Duarte had been unable to stand up to growing opposition to new talks from the political right and certain sectors of the Salvadoran military. They said also that prospects for peace talks could worsen if the political right makes gains in municipal and legislative elections scheduled for March.

headline.main: REBELS SAY DUARTE, PRESSED BY RIGHT, SHUNS TALKS

docs.snippet: Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, threw his arms around Mary Martin in the Jockey Club and started singing near the top of his lungs. ''Have yourself a Mary, Mary Martin,'' he sang.    ''How do you spell that?'' Mi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, threw his arms around Mary Martin in the Jockey Club and started singing near the top of his lungs. ''Have yourself a Mary, Mary Martin,'' he sang. ''How do you spell that?'' Miss Martin said. But Mr. Wick had already taken his act to another table.

byline.original: By JOHN DUKA, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: George Jones, a reserve guard inserted into the lineup after Tony McIntosh fouled out, scored 7 points in the final 1 minute 17 seconds of overtime to lead Fordham to a 73-67 victory over Manhattan College in a Metro Atlantic Conference game yeste...
docs.lead_paragraph: George Jones, a reserve guard inserted into the lineup after Tony McIntosh fouled out, scored 7 points in the final 1 minute 17 seconds of overtime to lead Fordham to a 73-67 victory over Manhattan College in a Metro Atlantic Conference game yesterday afternoon at Draddy Gymnasium in Riverdale. Jerry Hobbie scored 20 points for the Rams (12-5 over all, 4-1 in the conference). Steve Samuels added 17 points to boost his career total to 1,014 and become the 18th player in Fordham history to go over the 1,000-point mark. McIntosh followed with 16.

docs.snippet: Sydney Smith, the early 19th-century wit and divine, said that the parallelogram formed by Oxford Street, Piccadilly, Regent Street and Park Lane ''enclosed more intelligence and ability, to say nothing of wealth and beauty, than the world has eve...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sydney Smith, the early 19th-century wit and divine, said that the parallelogram formed by Oxford Street, Piccadilly, Regent Street and Park Lane ''enclosed more intelligence and ability, to say nothing of wealth and beauty, than the world has ever collected into such a space before.'' That would be harder to maintain of the Mayfair of today. The wealth and beauty has fled to Belgravia or Chelsea or obscure tax havens in the West Indies. The intelligence and ability, or such of it as has remained in London, is probably in Hampstead or Islington. Many of the buildings familiar to Smith have gone, too, thanks to speculators and the Luftwaffe. The house on Bruton Street where the present Queen was born is a dour, faceless bank. And Universal Pictures is ensconced on the Piccadilly site where the most notorious of Regency debauchees, the Duke of Queensberry, spent his declining years ogling women from a bow window. Old Q, as he was called, managed to keep alive and active until the age of 86, helped by a bath of milk every day and thousands of visits of two hours each from his doctor in the last seven years of his life. His house hasn't matched him for longevity.

byline.original: By Benedict Nightingale; BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE reports regularly on the theater from London

docs.snippet: Behind Bad Writing    What is the most common cause of bad writing? After a lifetime of writing and teaching, Jacques Barzun arrived at this answer in ''Simple & Direct: A Rhetoric For Writers'' (Harper & Row):      The root difficulty in all case...
docs.lead_paragraph: Behind Bad Writing What is the most common cause of bad writing? After a lifetime of writing and teaching, Jacques Barzun arrived at this answer in ''Simple & Direct: A Rhetoric For Writers'' (Harper & Row): The root difficulty in all cases was the state of being blind and deaf to words - not seeing the words for the prose. Being adults, they had forgotten what every child understands, which is that giving or taking a meaning is not automatic and inevitable. In reading, the adult merely thinks that such-and-such a writer is ''difficult'' or ''boring,'' ''long-winded'' or ''involved,'' as if these were inborn traits of character and not failures of craftsmanship. About their own work, writers of this description are either complacent - they can read it all right - or apologetic and resigned, as if the trouble lay in their genes.

docs.snippet: Willie Hernandez, the American League's most valuable player and Cy Young Award winner last season, has signed a guaranteed five-year contract with the Detroit Tigers worth $5 million to $5.5 million. The 30-year-old reliever had been under contra...
docs.lead_paragraph: Willie Hernandez, the American League's most valuable player and Cy Young Award winner last season, has signed a guaranteed five-year contract with the Detroit Tigers worth $5 million to $5.5 million. The 30-year-old reliever had been under contract through the 1985 season, but he opened the way for the lucrative new pact by demanding to be traded. . . . Oscar Gamble, the Yankee slugger, and two other players who had not found a team since going through the free-agent draft in November, were cleared to negotiate with any major league club yesterday after they had been selected by fewer than four clubs in the supplemental draft. The others are Bobby Castillo, who pitched for the Minnesota Twins, and Steve Nicosia, a catcher for the San Francisco Giants.
